files.description: This document describes various ways to use the `run.sh` script for executing system tests, including running specific files, classes, methods, scenarios, and scenario groups.
This document explains how to force the execution of disabled or skipped tests using the `-F` option, typically for tests related to features still under development.

This document explains how to use the 'replay' mode in system tests to significantly reduce execution time during development iteration. It details the usage, benefits, and limitations of this feature for faster test development.

This document explains the `--skip-empty-scenario` option for system tests execution, which deselects tests if a scenario contains only disabled tests. It also covers the equivalent environment variable.

This document provides instructions for setting up and running AWS-related system tests, including Pulumi installation, AWS client configuration checks, and details on which AWS accounts to use for CI versus local development.

This document provides instructions on how to run Datadog system tests, understand their results, and troubleshoot common issues. It explains the usage of `build.sh` and `run.sh` scripts, and interprets the various symbols used in the test summary.

This document explains the `xfail_strict` option for system tests, which causes the process to fail if an xfail-marked test unexpectedly passes (xpass). It details when to use this option (e.g., release process) and when to avoid it (e.g., CI) due to potential breakage.

This document provides troubleshooting steps and solutions for common errors encountered during the execution of system tests, covering issues related to Docker, build processes, environment setup, and specific platforms like Mac.
This document provides instructions on how to update and rebuild Docker images used in system tests, including steps for versioning, CI triggers, and pushing images to Docker Hub.

This document outlines the code formatting guidelines and tools used for system tests, primarily focusing on Python code with tools like mypy, black, and pylint. It also mentions formatting for other languages used in library apps.

This document describes how to use manifest files (e.g., YAML) to configure system test execution, specifying which tests are enabled, disabled, or skipped based on conditions like library versions, weblog types, or known issues. It details various entry formats and YAML syntax rules for these manifest files.

This document provides instructions on how to enable, run, and test system tests for changes in the `dd-trace` repository, including local testing, CI/CD workflows, and alternative approaches. It guides users through the process of integrating new features with existing system tests.
This document explains how to create and use custom scenarios within the `system-tests` framework, providing code examples for defining a scenario and applying it to pytest tests.

This document explains how the CI system determines which system test scenarios to execute based on file modifications within the repository. It details the logic for identifying targeted scenarios by changes in `tests/` and `tests/**/utils.py`.
This document provides guidelines on using decorators for skipping or conditionally running system tests, detailing when to use them, their types, parameters, and version formatting.

This document provides instructions on how to add new end-to-end tests to the system-tests repository, covering test structure, interaction with weblog applications, and validation using various interface validators.

This document serves as a comprehensive guide for developers on how to create, modify, and manage system tests within the Datadog system-tests repository. It covers adding new tests, modifying existing ones, and enabling/disabling tests, along with links to more detailed instructions for various related tasks.
This file is a glossary defining terms related to test activation, deactivation, and various test outcomes (e.g., pass, fail, xpass, xfail, skipped) within the system tests.
This document outlines the execution flow for Datadog system tests, detailing the steps for both normal and replay modes in end-to-end scenarios.

This document provides instructions on how to renew the self-signed MITM proxy certificate when it expires, which is necessary for system tests to function correctly. It outlines the steps to generate a new certificate and update related scripts.
This file documents the historical origin of the repository, noting it is a fork from legacy Sqreen System tests.
This document outlines the internal workflow for reviewing pull requests within the Datadog system-tests repository, detailing specific considerations for different types of code changes.
This file documents the minimal software requirements necessary to run the system tests.
This document describes how system tests manage data flushing before running assertions, detailing default, implicit, and explicit flushing mechanisms and their configuration.

This document proposes and describes a revamp of the asynchronous model for system tests, outlining changes to test execution logic, its benefits, and drawbacks. It details how the new model will simplify internals, improve debugging, and better integrate with native pytest features.
This file documents how to configure and interpret log levels (INFO, DEBUG) within the `pytest` framework for Datadog's system tests, specifically via `pytest.ini`.
This document describes the lifecycle and architecture of parametric scenarios used in system tests, which target libraries and utilize Docker containers and xdist for testing.
This document provides an in-depth look into the internal workings and architecture of the system tests for developers.

This directory contains documentation for deprecated Request for Comments (RFCs) related to the internal aspects of Datadog system tests. It serves as an archive for superseded or obsolete internal design proposals and specifications.

This file documents the internal life cycle and execution flow of end-to-end scenarios within the system tests. It details the startup sequence, health checks, and the three-step execution process (setup, wait, test) for these scenarios.
This document explains how to use the official reusable GitHub Actions workflow for running system tests in a repository. It details the workflow's configuration parameters and required secrets.
This document describes the CI workflow for system tests, detailing how GitHub Actions are triggered, the stages involved during a pull request, and options for targeting specific library branches.
This document provides instructions and examples for integrating system tests into various CI/CD pipelines. It covers setup steps, necessary tools, and references specific CI configurations.
This document provides instructions for adding secrets, specifically a GitHub token, to the CI environment for system tests, likely within GitLab CI.
This README file introduces the 'System tests' workbench, explaining its principles and providing guidance on how to run them locally, integrate them into CI, and add new test cases.

This document provides an architectural overview of the system-tests framework, detailing its components, how to build and run tests, and guidance for troubleshooting. It clarifies suitable use cases and common scenarios for system tests.
This document outlines the ownership structure within the system-tests repository, providing guidelines to identify the responsible team for various parts of the codebase.
This README file describes the purpose of the 'RFCs' folder, indicating that it contains old Request for Comments (RFCs).

This RFC proposes a new mechanism using 'manifest files' to declare test metadata and manage test activation or skipping in system tests. It aims to resolve conflicts encountered with the current decorator-based approach by offering a component-centric declaration method.
This document outlines the lifecycle and sequence of operations involved in running Datadog system tests, from setting up proxies and services to executing tests and exporting logs.

This document describes the provision system used in Datadog's AWS SSI system tests. It details how to define and structure virtual machine setups for testing, outlining both scenario and weblog provisions and their components for installing software and configuring environments.
This `__init__.py` file marks the 'tests' directory as a Python package, enabling its modules to be imported within the system-tests suite.

This README file outlines the conventions and best practices for structuring tests within the `system-tests` directory. It details how features, feature variations, and use cases should be mapped to test files, classes, and methods, respectively.

This directory stores VCR (Video Cassette Recorder) cassettes specifically for recording and replaying HTTP interactions with the OpenAI API. These cassettes are used within integration tests to ensure deterministic and fast test execution without relying on live network calls to OpenAI services.

This directory is intended to house test fixtures, which are pre-defined data, states, or configurations used to set up the environment for system tests within the Datadog repository. Its purpose is to provide consistent and reusable test resources for the associated system tests.
Provides a utility function to run system tests with various configurations and parse their results from a generated JSON report.

This file contains unit tests for the DockerScenario class, verifying its ability to correctly resolve and manage container startup order based on dependencies, including detection of circular dependencies.

This file contains system tests to verify the behavior of the `@bug` and `@missing_feature` decorators, particularly focusing on how the `force_skip` argument impacts test outcomes (skipped vs. xpassed).

This file contains a system test that verifies file naming conventions within the 'tests' directory, ensuring that non-test Python files adhere to a strict set of allowed names (e.g., utils.py, conftest.py, __init__.py).

This file contains unit tests for the `parse_artifact_data` function, which processes test reports to extract information about test outcomes (like xpassed/xfailed tests) and related metadata for different libraries and weblog variants.

This file contains system tests to validate the structure, format, and content of the `capabilities.yml` configuration file. It ensures the YAML file adheres to its JSON schema and contains valid, non-duplicate capabilities for each language.

This file contains unit tests for the `compute_libraries_and_scenarios` utility script, which determines relevant libraries and test scenarios for CI/CD pipelines based on changed files and environment variables.

This file defines a suite of system tests designed to verify the correct generation and content of JUnit XML reports for various pytest outcomes. It runs a set of predefined test cases and then compares the generated JUnit report against an expected, normalized XML structure.
This file contains a test for the `get_endtoend_definitions` function, ensuring it correctly generates end-to-end test definitions, weblogs, and parallel jobs based on provided scenarios.
This file contains unit tests for the `scenarios` decorator functionality, specifically verifying its ability to apply multiple scenario decorators to a single test class.
This file contains system tests for the test runner's 'strict mode' functionality, ensuring that tests marked as bugs or missing features fail when strict mode is enabled.

This file contains tests to validate the correct assignment and exclusion of scenarios from predefined groups, ensuring consistency for 'appsec_rasp' and 'tracer_release' scenario groups within the test framework.

This file contains a test that verifies the uniqueness of `EndToEndScenario` configurations and environment variables within the test suite. It aims to identify redundant scenarios that could be merged, ensuring an efficient and minimal set of test cases.
This file contains unit tests for custom pytest decorators and utilities, verifying their behavior related to skipping, xfailing, and metadata application on test classes and methods.

This file contains a test that validates the naming conventions and accessibility of all defined test scenarios, ensuring they follow a specific uppercase format and are correctly exposed as properties of the `scenarios` object.

This file contains unit tests for the `Manifest` utility, which is responsible for parsing, validating, and applying skip/include declarations for system tests based on component versions and weblog configurations.

This file contains system tests to verify the integrity and correctness of a generated JSON test report, ensuring that various test outcomes, metadata, and decorator effects are accurately reflected in the report structure.

This file contains system tests to verify the `force` option functionality for test execution. It ensures that specific tests can be forced to run, overriding default skipping or xfailing behavior based on decorators or scenarios.

This file contains meta-tests for the system-tests framework, ensuring that all test classes properly declare features using decorators and that these feature decorators themselves are correctly defined and documented.

This directory contains manifests specifically designed for editing or modifying Python-related test configurations within the `test_the_test` system test suite. These manifests likely define how certain Python-based tests are adjusted or customized.

This directory is intended to store reference manifests used by system tests. These manifests likely serve as baseline configurations for tests validating the testing framework's ability to handle or process manifest files. Its current emptiness suggests these resources may be dynamically generated or are yet to be populated.

This directory is intended to contain tests specifically for the parser responsible for handling manifests within the system testing framework. Its purpose is to validate the correctness and robustness of the manifest parsing logic, likely as part of the framework's own test suite (meta-testing).

This file contains system tests to verify the correct behavior of custom test decorators like `@slow` and `@scenario_crash`, and `pytest.mark.skip_if_xfail`. It checks how these decorators interact with test declarations (e.g., `@bug`, `@missing_feature`) or manifest files to determine when tests should be skipped or executed.
This README file explains that the `utils` directory within the `system-tests` repository contains internal utilities for testing purposes.

This file serves as the main entry point for the 'utils' package, aggregating and exposing various utility functions, decorators, and core components for system tests. It makes key functionalities directly accessible when the 'utils' package is imported.

This file defines utilities for parsing cgroup information to extract container and pod IDs from system cgroup files. It provides a class to parse cgroup lines and a function to retrieve a container ID from a list of such lines.
This file defines host ports for various language-specific 'buddy' services and creates instances to represent them. It likely configures access to these services within a system testing framework.

This file provides utility functions for system tests, including loading environment variables from a .env file, colored terminal output, and helpers for extracting request IDs from spans and performing nested data lookups.

This file provides custom pytest decorators for marking tests as skipped or expected to fail based on conditions like known bugs, missing features, or specific environments, and for enforcing Jira ticket references.
This file defines an enumeration of host ports used by containers within system tests, specifically listing ports like the one for VCR cassettes.

This file defines abstract and concrete classes for managing the infrastructure of a weblog application within system tests, including its container setup, environment configuration, and lifecycle (start/stop) with various database and messaging dependencies.

This file defines a singleton class that centralizes and exposes properties and configurations relevant to the current system test scenario. It provides a consistent interface to access test context details such as agent version, weblog variant, and library information.

This file provides a cached utility function (`get_docker_client`) to obtain a Docker client instance, handling various connection methods (from environment or via Docker contexts) and error scenarios.

Provides utilities and a base class (`TestedContainer`) for defining, configuring, and managing the lifecycle of Docker containers used within system tests, including network, volume, and dependency management.
Defines an end-to-end test scenario for verifying agent/library communication using IPv6 addresses, ensuring the agent correctly handles IPv6 traffic.

This file defines the `IntegrationFrameworksScenario` class, which configures and manages testing scenarios for various integration frameworks (e.g., OpenAI, Anthropic) across different programming languages within a Dockerized environment.

This file defines classes for organizing and managing test scenarios within a pytest-based system testing framework. It includes `ScenarioGroup` for grouping tests and `Scenario` for configuring individual test contexts, logging, and integration with pytest hooks.

This file defines base classes for Docker-based system tests, particularly the `EndToEndScenario` which orchestrates an instrumented web application, a Datadog agent, and a proxy for comprehensive end-to-end testing within a Docker environment.
This file defines and organizes a collection of predefined test scenarios for system-tests, each configured for specific testing purposes like AppSec, OpenTelemetry, profiling, or sampling.
Defines a specific test scenario for system tests, configuring component versions and metadata for testing the testing infrastructure or specific application variants like 'spring'.

This file defines a `GoProxiesScenario` for Datadog system tests, orchestrating the setup and teardown of Docker containers to test web applications with different Go-based proxy components (Envoy, HAProxy) and processing services.

This file defines constants for different runtime environments (Java, PHP, Python, Node.js, .NET, Ruby) and their supported installable versions, along with utility methods to retrieve these versions.

This file provides utility functions to resolve and standardize runtime version identifiers for various programming languages used within the Docker System-level Integration (SSI) matrix, mapping runtime names to specific version IDs.
This module provides utility functions for handling Docker images specifically in a Kubernetes context.

This file implements a singleton parser for managing Kubernetes component versions from a `k8s_components.json` configuration file, allowing retrieval of default or all versions and updating pinned versions.
This file contains auto-generated gRPC client and server interfaces for the 'Weblog' service, defining methods for various communication patterns (unary, streaming) using Protobuf `Value` messages.
This file defines common data structures, including an enumeration for log levels and a typed dictionary for linking entities, likely used as fixtures or utilities within Datadog's system tests.

This file serves as the `__init__.py` for the `docker_fixtures` package, exposing core utilities for Docker operations, test agent management, and client testing APIs/factories. It aggregates components for setting up and interacting with Docker-based test environments.

This file provides utility functions and a context manager for managing Docker containers within a testing framework, including deterministic port allocation, volume configuration, and container lifecycle management (run, log, stop, remove).
This `__init__.py` file serves as the package entry point for test clients, aggregating and exposing various API and factory classes for framework integrations and parametric tests.

This file defines the `TestClientFactory` class, which is responsible for building Docker images used in system tests. It handles the Docker image build process, manages build arguments, and provides utilities for accessing image properties and logging.

This file defines the infrastructure and API for testing Datadog tracers in a parametric scenario, managing Docker containers for different tracers and providing methods to interact with them via a standardized client.

This directory is designated to hold schema definitions for version 0.5 of a library interface. These schemas are likely utilized by the `datadog` system tests to validate data structures and ensure correct interaction within the testing environment.

This directory is responsible for storing data schemas specific to version 0.6 of various library interfaces. These schemas are utilized within Datadog's system tests to define and validate the structure of data exchanged through these interfaces, ensuring consistency and correctness.
This script formats and validates the manifest for system tests, ensuring its correctness and consistency.

This file serves as the package initializer for the 'manifest' utility, re-exporting core classes and types related to manifest creation, test declarations, and conditions from its internal implementation for direct access.
This script serves as a standalone entry point to validate the manifest using the `Manifest` class. It ensures the integrity and correctness of the manifest configuration.
This file defines custom types for managing test manifest data, including custom semantic versioning rules, skip declarations, and structured conditions for test deactivation.

This `__init__.py` file serves as an internal package interface, exposing core components like `Manifest`, `TestDeclaration`, `SkipDeclaration`, and `Condition` for defining system test structures and behaviors.

This file defines constants, including regular expressions for parsing versioning and skip reasons, and an enumeration for various test declaration types like 'bug' or 'flaky'. It centralizes these definitions for use within the system tests' manifest utilities.
This script sorts entries within YAML-like manifest files in a given directory. It reads, parses, sorts manifest entries by their test paths, and then rewrites the files with the sorted content.

This file provides utility functions to validate YAML manifest files. It checks their structure against a JSON schema, verifies the order of keys, and dynamically confirms the existence of referenced Python classes and functions using both module imports and AST parsing.

This file defines a `Manifest` class that parses, validates, and applies rules to manifest files. It manages and filters declarations, such as test skips, based on specified component versions and weblog configurations.

This file provides utility functions for matching conditions against component versions and weblogs, and for matching rules against node IDs. It is used to determine which rules (e.g., test skip declarations) are applicable based on a given manifest and environmental context.

This file defines the `Declaration` class, which parses and validates raw declaration strings from manifest files. It distinguishes between skip declarations and semantic version range declarations, extracting relevant details like versions, skip types, and optional reasons.

This file is responsible for parsing and processing YAML manifest files into structured Python objects (`ManifestData` and `Condition` objects), applying various field transformations and validations to define test skipping rules and configurations.
This `__init__.py` file marks the `onboarding` directory as a Python package, allowing its modules and subpackages to be imported.
This directory is designated to store assets, static resources, or test data required by the system tests. Its purpose is to provide supporting files for test execution within the `utils` framework.
This README file provides a brief description for miscellaneous utility scripts located in the system-tests repository that are not directly involved in testing.
This script retrieves and prints a sorted list of scenario names that belong to a specified scenario group. It normalizes the provided group name to match internal definitions.
This script crawls specified directories and file types to find Jira ticket IDs, then automatically adds the 'system-tests' label to those tickets in Jira using the API.

This script generates a Docker Compose YAML configuration that lists all external Docker images required for running specified system test scenarios, excluding images that are built locally or already exist on the system.

This script automates the update of Kubernetes component pinned versions (e.g., Datadog Cluster Agent, Operator, and Helm Chart) by fetching the latest stable versions from Docker images and Artifact Hub, then updating a configuration file.

This script generates a changelog by fetching merged pull requests from the 'DataDog/system-tests' GitHub repository for a specified or the last completed month, filtering for PRs with a 'changelog' label.

A script that retrieves information about a GitHub Actions workflow run, identifies failing jobs and steps, and then prints a formatted summary of these failures to the console or a specified output file.
This script parses JUnit XML test reports from a directory to aggregate test results, categorize them by outcome and codeowners, and generate a markdown summary.

This script computes the set of libraries and test scenarios that need to be run or are impacted based on changes in source code files, manifest differences, or PR titles. It determines which system tests should be executed in a CI/CD pipeline.

This script automates the cleanup of old and unused AWS resources, such as AMIs and their associated snapshots, and potentially EC2 instances, that are tagged for 'system-tests'. It also reports relevant metrics to Datadog.

This script computes and formats parameters for Continuous Integration (CI) workflows, primarily for system tests, based on specified libraries, scenarios, and groups. It exports the generated workflow data in various formats like GitHub, GitLab, or JSON.

This directory is intended to house scripts or utilities specifically designed for Slack integration within the system tests. It would likely contain tools for sending test results, alerts, or other relevant notifications to Slack channels.
This script cleans a PEM file by extracting and retaining only the RSA private key block, overwriting the original file with just the key content. It is designed to be run as a command-line utility.

This directory is designated to contain utility scripts related to Artificial Intelligence, specifically for use within the system tests of the Datadog repository. Although currently empty, it serves as a placeholder for AI-driven testing tools or data processing scripts.

This file contains utilities for generating test matrices and configurations for system tests across different environments (Kubernetes, AWS, Docker), mapping scenarios to weblogs, virtual machines, or Docker images and runtimes.

This script acts as a GitLab CI orchestrator, dynamically generating `.gitlab-ci.yml` configurations for system tests, particularly for AWS SSI, Docker SSI, and Kubernetes lib-injection scenarios. It customizes the pipeline based on scenario definitions and CI environment variables, including determining appropriate Kubernetes component versions.
This script activates 'easy wins' by processing test artifacts, updating a manifest based on the findings, and reporting on the changes, with options for dry-runs and component filtering.
Defines a `Context` dataclass for managing library, version, and variant information, including logic to normalize version strings by stripping build metadata for Java.
This file defines constants for an internal script, including a list of programming libraries and a URL for fetching system test artifact information.
This `__init__.py` file defines the `_internal` Python package. It contains internal implementation modules for activating 'easy wins' within the system tests.

This file handles downloading and parsing test reports from GitHub CI artifacts. It extracts test outcomes, organizes them by context, and builds a trie structure to represent the activation status of tests.

This file defines a `ManifestEditor` class used to load, parse, and programmatically modify YAML manifest files. It handles nuances of YAML parsing like anchor references used as keys and allows for adding or updating rules based on specific test contexts.

This file contains the core logic for processing test data to update a test manifest, activating or deactivating tests based on their status (e.g., XPASS/XFAIL). It also generates detailed reports on test activations, rule modifications, and code owner statistics.

This directory is designated for scripts and utilities that support parametric testing within the system-tests framework. It is intended to manage or generate various parameters for test configurations. Although currently empty, its role is to facilitate flexible and data-driven testing.
This README provides instructions on managing auto-generated files within the telemetry intake utility, specifically advising against manual updates and providing a script for proper updating.
This file contains a utility function for parsing Nginx configuration files. It extracts application details from specific return directives within the Nginx configuration structure.

This file implements an AWS virtual machine provider using Pulumi, responsible for provisioning, configuring, and destroying AWS EC2 instances for system testing purposes. It manages SSH connections, handles provisioning errors, and interacts with virtual machine configurations.

This file defines an abstract interface for virtual machine providers and orchestrates the provisioning and installation of various components on virtual machines across different platforms (e.g., AWS, Vagrant, KrunVM) for system tests.
This file defines the `VirtualMachineProvisioner` class, which parses YAML configuration files to manage and define the provisioning steps for virtual machines used in system tests.
This file implements a virtual machine provider using krunvm to create and manage microVMs for system tests, handling their lifecycle, command execution, and file transfers.

This file defines data structures and a core class for managing virtual machines used in system tests, handling their configuration (AWS, Vagrant, KrunVM), SSH access, provisioning, and environment setup.

This file implements a virtual machine provider (`VagrantProvider`) and a command executor (`VagrantCommander`) for managing and interacting with Vagrant-based virtual machines. It handles VM lifecycle operations like creation, configuration, and destruction, as well as executing commands and copying files/folders on the provisioned VMs.
This file initializes the Promptfoo package for a local cursor provider, making it discoverable as a Python module.

This file configures Claude AI for system tests by listing the various rule files it must follow and providing a quick reference to the project details. It acts as an index to the actual AI assistant rules located in the `.cursor/rules/` directory.

This directory is intended to house rules or configurations for the `.cursor` tool, specifically within the context of system tests. While currently empty, it serves as a designated placeholder for defining custom behaviors or analysis parameters for this part of the repository.

APM & Distributed Tracing.description: Provides end-to-end visibility into application performance by tracing requests across distributed services, containers, and serverless functions, helping teams identify bottlenecks and resolve issues.

files.description: This document provides instructions and prerequisites for running and contributing to end-to-end tests within the system-tests repository, with a focus on APM E2E tests. It also offers guidance on adding new test scenarios.

This document explains how system-tests interprets and uses SemVer, including pre-release and build suffixes. It provides guidelines for activating tests against different versions (released vs. development) and offers specific versioning conventions for various tracer libraries.

This document details the `_BackendInterfaceValidator` class, which uses direct API calls to the Datadog backend to validate that traces, spans, metrics, and logs have been properly ingested and processed. It covers usage, configuration, available methods, and best practices for end-to-end testing.
This file provides documentation explaining what weblogs are within Datadog system tests and outlines their different types and uses.

This document describes the various endpoints and their expected behavior for weblog applications used in Datadog's end-to-end system tests. These weblogs mimic real instrumented HTTP applications to validate the library's functionality across different platforms.
This document details the setup and execution of APM library parametric tests, designed to validate all APM libraries against a shared interface using common test cases.
This README provides a brief introduction to the end-to-end APM tracing tests and directs users to the main documentation for comprehensive details.
This file serves as a redirect, pointing users to the comprehensive documentation for parametric tests located in `docs/scenarios/parametric.md`.

This pytest conftest.py file provides fixtures and utilities for setting up and managing testing environments for Datadog APM libraries in parametric system tests, including configuring test agents, client libraries, and writing stable configurations.

This file provides utility functions for hashing and validating 'span pointers' within the Datadog system tests. It includes a standard hashing function and a factory for creating span link validators to assert span link attributes.

This file provides a utility class `_Weblog` for Datadog system tests, enabling interaction with a weblog service via HTTP and gRPC requests, including request/response serialization and request ID injection.

This file defines a `PerformanceScenario` class, extending `EndToEndScenario`, which configures and executes performance-oriented tests. It includes a weblog warmup routine and dynamically enables/disables AppSec based on an environment variable for testing different configurations.

This file defines a `ParametricScenario` class for running parametric system tests against various APM client libraries. It handles the setup, configuration, and execution of these tests, including building Docker images for test clients and persisting test context across distributed test runs.

This file is a Python output generated by the protocol buffer compiler (protoc) from the `weblog.proto` definition. It defines the Python classes and service stubs for gRPC communication with a 'Weblog' service, including methods for unary, server streaming, client streaming, and bidirectional streaming calls.

This file defines utilities for testing framework integrations by abstracting the setup and interaction with a Dockerized test server running a tracer and a specific framework. It provides classes to build, run, and communicate with these test environments.

This file defines constants, data structures, and helper methods for working with trace data and protocols, including decoding V0.6 stats payloads and utility functions for finding and asserting properties of traces and spans.
This file defines utility classes for validating HTTP headers in system tests. It includes validators to check for header presence and to verify if header values match specified regular expressions.

This file defines a validator class (`_BackendInterfaceValidator`) responsible for interacting with the Datadog backend. It provides methods to fetch and assert the existence of traces and spans submitted by tracers to the Datadog platform.
This file provides utility functions and a class for validating different types of tags, specifically for spans and process-related information, often used within system tests.
This file provides utility functions for filtering spans from a list of traces based on a given request ID (rid), commonly used within system tests to process trace data.

This file defines a `LibraryInterfaceValidator` class used in system tests to interact with and validate data reported by Datadog tracers to an agent. It provides methods for retrieving and filtering traces, spans, AppSec events, and telemetry data from the agent's various endpoints.

This file provides utility functions for interacting with the Datadog backend API to retrieve and validate trace and profile data, including robust request handling with retries and API key management, primarily for system testing.
This file defines an IntEnum class, `ProxyPorts`, which enumerates various port numbers used by a proxy to identify the source of incoming requests within system tests.

This file defines a framework for mocking HTTP responses in a proxy, including abstract and concrete classes for simulating tracer and backend responses during system tests. It allows for dynamic modification of HTTP flows by intercepting requests and customizing responses based on predefined rules.

This file defines the core logic for a proxy used in Datadog system tests, handling request routing, logging, and mocking responses for various components like tracers, agents, and weblogs to facilitate testing scenarios.
This document explains how to recreate protobuf schemas used for traces, referencing their origin in the `datadog-agent` repository and detailing the update process.
Tests how tracers serialize and transmit span events, differentiating between agent support for native formats and specific serialization versions (v0.4, v0.5, v0.7).

This system test file verifies the basic generation and existence of traces by making a request to the `/spans` endpoint. It includes conditional logic related to Unix Domain Sockets support for certain weblog configurations.

This file contains system tests to validate that web framework traces generated by Datadog's instrumentations adhere to established semantic conventions for span metadata. It defines expected component names for various web frameworks and verifies the presence and format of critical HTTP-related meta tags in spans.

This file contains system tests to verify the correct extraction of the `http.endpoint` tag from weblog responses and to ensure that stats aggregation properly uses HTTP method and endpoint as keys for resource renaming.
This file contains system tests to verify the structure and content of V1 APM trace payloads, focusing on efficient payload features sent by the tracing library and received by the agent.

This file contains system tests to verify that process tags are correctly present and validated in various data payloads, including tracing, remote configuration, and telemetry data, generated by the agent or client libraries.

This file contains system tests to verify that various libraries correctly annotate spans with standard HTTP tags, such as `http.method`, `http.url`, `http.useragent`, `http.status_code`, and `http.route`.

This file contains system tests to verify the partial flushing feature of Datadog tracing libraries. It includes tests for various configurations, such as explicit enabling/disabling and different minimum span thresholds for partial flushes.

This module provides unit tests for Datadog tracing parametric endpoints, verifying their functionality and feature parity across different libraries. It ensures that critical tracing operations like span creation, finishing, header injection/extraction, and metadata setting work as expected.

This file contains system tests for the Datadog tracer, verifying that traces and spans correctly capture basic attributes, source code integration (SCI) tags, universal service tags (e.g., DD_SERVICE, DD_ENV), and process tags based on environment variables.

This file contains system tests for validating how Datadog APM libraries compute, aggregate, and report trace statistics to the Datadog Agent. It verifies scenarios such as metrics serialization, distinct aggregation keys, measured spans, and top-level spans.

This file contains system tests for the V1 trace deserialization logic, verifying the correct processing of msgpack-encoded HTTP messages and the uncompression of agent V1 traces, including base64-encoded trace IDs and span link attributes.
This file contains system tests for verifying client-side trace statistics computation and aggregation, including peer tags, obfuscation, and feature detection via the agent's `/info` endpoint.

Web Application Firewall (WAF).description: Protects web applications from common threats and attacks in real-time by inspecting HTTP traffic and applying a robust set of security rules to block malicious requests.

files.description: This file contains system tests for Datadog AppSec IP blocking functionality, specifically verifying that the full denylist correctly blocks requests from a large number of specified IP addresses while allowing others.

This file contains system tests for Datadog's Application Security (AppSec) feature, specifically verifying that the security library correctly blocks requests when rules are set to blocking mode via remote configuration.

This file tests how AppSec's suspicious attacker blocking feature, configured via remote configuration, dynamically applies different blocking actions (e.g., custom HTTP status codes) based on IP reputation and other rules. It verifies that requests from suspicious IPs are blocked according to the remote config settings.

This file contains system tests for AppSec user blocking functionality using a full denylist. It verifies that non-denylisted users are not blocked and that denylisted users trigger WAF attacks and result in blocked requests with appropriate span metadata.

This file contains system tests for Datadog's Application Security (AppSec) feature, verifying its ability to block requests based on various attributes like client IP, user ID, request method, and URI. It ensures that requests are blocked correctly and that blocking occurs early in the request processing pipeline.

This file contains system tests for verifying that the `security_response_id` (as defined by RFC-1070) is correctly included, formatted, and unique across different AppSec blocking response types (JSON, HTML, redirect URLs) and within associated trace spans.

This file contains system tests for the Application Security (AppSec) WAF blocking functionality. It verifies that the WAF returns correct blocking responses (status code, content type, and body template) based on various `Accept` header configurations and confirms the presence of the `appsec.blocked` tag in traces.

This file contains system tests for Datadog AppSec's extended header collection feature. It verifies that request and response headers are correctly collected and adhere to configured limits, especially when an AppSec event is triggered.

This file contains system tests for the Application Security (AppSec) rate limiter. It verifies that the rate limiter correctly restricts the number of traces generated by AppSec when a high volume of requests is processed.

This file contains system tests to verify that AppSec-related client IP tags are not reported in spans when AppSec is disabled. It ensures that no IP-related metadata is added by the library under these conditions.

This file contains system tests for Datadog's Application Security (AppSec) module, verifying that it correctly reports various event details such as HTTP status codes, service information, request headers, rule-related tags, and attack timestamps.
This file contains system tests for AppSec WAF truncation, verifying that the WAF correctly processes and reports metrics when handling large or deeply nested input data that exceeds its limits.

This file contains system tests for the AppSec WAF's rule and input exclusion functionalities. It verifies that WAF attacks are correctly detected or suppressed based on the active exclusion rules.
This file contains exhaustive system tests for the Web Application Firewall (WAF) default rule set, covering various attack types like scanners, LFI, RFI, command injection, XSS, SQLI, and NoSQLi.

This file contains miscellaneous system tests for the AppSec WAF, covering scenarios such as detecting attacks on 404 pages, reporting multiple attacks within a single request, and verifying case-sensitive rule processing.

This file contains system tests for the Application Security (AppSec) WAF, verifying its ability to detect and block attacks in various parts of HTTP requests, including URL queries, headers, cookies, and different body formats (URL-encoded, JSON, XML).
